Sure, here's a table that emphasizes the pages and navigation of the web app, as well as the actions available on each page and the corresponding user flows:

| Page | Navigation | Actions | User Flows |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Home Page | Logo, Navigation Menu, Search Bar | - Search for a destination by name or location- Browse recommended destinations and travel deals | - User enters a search query and is taken to the search results page- User clicks on a recommended destination and is taken to the destination page |
| Search Results Page | Navigation Menu, Search Bar | - Refine search results by date, weather, or activities- View summary of each search result | - User selects filters and the search results update accordingly- User clicks on a search result and is taken to the destination page |
| Destination Page | Navigation Menu, Booking Form | - View detailed information about the destination- Book travel arrangements | - User reads information about the destination- User fills out booking form and submits it |
| Reviews Page | Navigation Menu, Search Bar, Review Form | - Search for reviews by destination or activity- Leave a review or rating for a destination or activity | - User enters a search query and is taken to the search results page- User fills out review form and submits it |
| Account Page | Navigation Menu, Account Settings | - View and edit account information- View booking history and current trip status | - User navigates to account settings and makes changes- User views booking history and current trip status |

This layout shows the main pages of the web app, the navigation available on each page, the actions that can be taken on each page, and the corresponding user flows for those actions.
